column5: The text provided would likely not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature. However, the text provided does not appear to contain any such communications. Rather, it is a brief email discussing the logistics of a meeting and the topics that will be discussed. There is no indication that the email contains any predecisional or deliberative information. Therefore, it is unlikely that exemption 5 would apply.; ; There is no specific case law cited to support this conclusion, as the text provided is relatively straightforward and does not present any complex legal issues. However, the general principles underlying exemption 5 are well-established and have been applied in numerous cases. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Similarly, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 applies to "documents that are both predecisional and deliberative, meaning that they reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process." Based on these and other cases, it is clear that exemption 5 is intended to protect certain types of communications that are part of the decision-making process, but not all communications between government officials.

In that case, the court held that certain communications between the White House and the Department of Justice were exempt from disclosure under exemption 5 because they were both predecisional and deliberative in nature. However, the court also noted that not all presidential communications are automatically exempt from disclosure, and that the specific content of the records must be evaluated on a case-by-case basis to determine whether they meet the requirements of the exemption.

It is not clear whether the record would be protected under FOIA exemption 5 without additional information. Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. The record provided appears to be a note from Jennifer L. Klein to Elena Kagan, but it is unclear whether it is an inter-agency or intra-agency communication, or whether it is pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. Additionally, the content of the note is not provided, so it is impossible to determine whether it contains information that would be protected under exemption 5. Therefore, it is not possible to determine whether the record would be protected under exemption 5 without additional information. ; ; No case law is cited as the record provided is insufficient to make a determination.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; RECORD TYPE: PRESIDENTIAL   {NOTES MAIL) CREATOR: Jennifer L. Klein ( CN=Jennifer L. Klein/OU=OPD/O=EOP ( OPD] ) CREATION DATE/TIME:25 -NOV -1997 18:32:37.00 SUBJECT: TO: Elena Kagan ( CN=Elena Kagan/QU;OPD/O=EOP@ EOP [ OPD] ) READ:UNKNOWN; ; We are developing a child care proposal that will help working families afford child care, make targeted investments to improve the safety and quality of child care, particularly for infants and toddlers, and provide safe, constructive activities for school-age children. To help working families afford child care, the proposal: (1) increases funding for federal child care subsidies through the Child Care and Development Block Grant; and (2) changes the Child and Dependent Care Tax Credit by raising the percentage of child care expenses  for which a  taxpayer may take a credit and by increasing the income levels of taxpayers who may  claim it. Currently, the credit rate is phased down from 30% for taxpayers with adjusted gross income of $10,000 or less to 20% for taxpayers with AGI above $28,000.  We are considering a series of options, including raising the credit rate from 50% for taxpayers with AGI of $30,000 to 20% for those with AGI above $59,000.)  We are also considering targeted investments to improve  the safety and quality of care.    First, the proposal adds funding to the scholarship program for child care providers, which you announced at the child care conference and  which has  received strong support. Second, it includes a new program that will ensure safety and healthy early learning and development for children in the critical first years. Third, the proposal provides resources for states to improve their enforcement of health and safety standards, and fourth, it funds parent education, research and technology. Finally, the proposal makes safe, constructive activities for youth during after-school hours more available by creating a new program for school age children and by coordinating existing programs.
column5: The record described would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a communication between two officials within the Executive Office of the President (EOP) regarding a child care proposal. As such, it is likely that the communication would be considered privileged and therefore exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. ; ; This conclusion is supported by case law such as NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), which established that the deliberative process privilege protects communications that are part of the decision-making process within an agency. The privilege applies to communications that are predecisional and deliberative, meaning they are made before a final decision is reached and are intended to help shape that decision. The record described appears to be just such a communication, as it discusses options that are being considered as part of the child care proposal. ; ; Additionally, the fact that the record was created by an official within the EOP further supports the conclusion that it would be protected under exemption 5. The EOP is considered to be an extension of the President and is therefore entitled to a greater degree of confidentiality than other agencies. This was established in United States v. Nixon, 418 U.S. 683 (1974), which held that the President's communications with his advisors are presumptively privileged and can only be overcome by a showing of need that outweighs the public interest in confidentiality. While the record described may not be a direct communication with the President, it was created by an official within the EOP and is therefore entitled to a similar degree of protection.

However, without more information about the context and content of the communication, it is difficult to make a definitive determination. ; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. This privilege is intended to protect the decision-making process within agencies by allowing officials to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure. However, the privilege is not absolute and may be overcome if the public interest in disclosure outweighs the government's interest in confidentiality.

column5: It is possible that this record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, more information would be needed to make a definitive determination. The record appears to be a communication between various individuals within the Executive Office of the President, including the President's counsel and senior advisors. If the communication contains legal advice or other privileged information, it could be protected under exemption 5. However, if it is simply a routine administrative communication, it may not be protected. ; ; One case that could be relevant is In re Sealed Case, 121 F.3d 729 (D.C. Cir. 1997), which established a three-part test for determining whether a document is protected under exemption 5. The test looks at whether the document is (1) predecisional, (2) deliberative, and (3) contains information that would be privileged in civil litigation. If the document meets all three criteria, it may be protected. However, the court noted that exemption 5 should be narrowly construed and that agencies should not use it to withhold information that is not truly privileged.

The fact that the notes were created by a member of the Executive Office of the President (EOP) and sent to another member of the EOP suggests that they were part of an internal communication within the government. Additionally, the subject matter of the notes being presidential in nature further supports the argument that they were part of privileged communications. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "those documents, and only those documents, that are normally privileged in the civil discovery context." The Court further explained that the exemption is intended to protect "confidential communications between Government officials" and to encourage "candid discussion within the Government." Fernandes' notes would likely fall within this category of protected communications.

column5: It is possible that the record described could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a communication between various individuals within the Executive Office of the President, including high-level officials such as the President's Chief of Staff and Counselor. The fact that the record is labeled as a "Presidential" record and includes individuals from multiple offices within the EOP suggests that it may contain privileged advice or deliberations related to the President's decision-making process.; ; However, without more information about the content of the record, it is difficult to make a definitive determination about whether it would be protected under exemption 5. The Supreme Court has held that the exemption applies to materials that are both predecisional and deliberative, meaning that they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions, recommendations, or other information related to the decision-making process. See NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132, 150-51 (1975). The D.C. Circuit has also emphasized that the exemption is intended to protect the "give-and-take" of the decision-making process, rather than simply shielding any document that happens to be labeled as "deliberative." See Tax Analysts v. IRS, 117 F.3d 607, 618 (D.C. Cir. 1997).; ; Therefore, whether the record described would be protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific content of the communication and whether it meets the criteria for predecisional and deliberative materials.

column5: The record described would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a communication between high-level officials in the Executive Office of the President, discussing a list of conservative individuals or groups. This communication could potentially be considered pre-decisional and deliberative, as it appears to be part of the process of developing a strategy or policy position. ; ; One case that supports this interpretation is Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004). In that case, the D.C. Circuit held that a memorandum from a White House counsel to the President, discussing legal advice and recommendations, was protected under exemption 5 as pre-decisional and deliberative. The court noted that the memorandum was "part of the consultative process by which the President obtains the advice of his closest advisors" and that disclosure would "chill the candor and limit the range of information and advice provided to the President." Similarly, the communication described in the record appears to be part of a consultative process among high-level officials, and disclosure could similarly chill candor and limit the range of information and advice provided.

Reed/OPD/EOP, Elena Kagan/OPD/EOP cc: Subject: Need for Closure on Radiation Report Release Date; ; Io October, 1995 ACHRE issued its report. ACHRE found that the-government had conducted several thousand human radiation experiments from 1945 to 1975 and that the majority advanced biomedical research. The Committee found, however, that some were conducted unethically. For example, scientists injected plutonium into 18 patients without their knowledge, and researchers conducted experiments on indigent patients and children. ACHRE made 18 recommendations to open the public record, protect human subjects of future research, and compensate those wronged by the government's actions.
column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The text appears to be a communication between two officials within the Executive Office of the President (EOP) discussing the release date of a radiation report. This communication could be considered privileged because it involves internal deliberations and decision-making within the EOP. ; ; There is no specific case law cited in the text to support this conclusion, but courts have generally interpreted exemption 5 broadly to protect the decision-making process within agencies. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." ; ; Therefore, unless there is a compelling public interest in disclosure that outweighs the need for confidentiality, this communication would likely be exempt from disclosure under FOIA exemption 5.

Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies" by allowing officials to communicate candidly and freely without fear of public disclosure.; ; Therefore, unless there is a compelling public interest in disclosure that outweighs the need for confidentiality, the content of the email would likely be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Elizabeth Drye 03/24/97. 06:13:24 PM Record Type:    Record To: Bruce N. Reed/OPD/EOP, Elena Kagan/OPD/EOP cc: Subject: Need for Closure on Radiation Report Release Date; ;     • President Clinton signed a memorandum to strengthen the rights and protections of people participating in secret, government-supported research. ACHRE recommended that subjects of secret experiments have special protections and information. Acting on that recommendation, the President directed agencies today to propose new rules for secret research that would require scientists to: obtain informed consent from all potential subjects of all secret experiments (current rules allow researchers to waive informed consent in certain cases); disclose the identity of the sponsoring agency to potential subjects; and tell potential subjects that an experiment is classified. The new rules would also establish a more independent review process; require the head of the agency conducting secret human research to approve each project; and require permanent records of secret experiments. The President also directed federal agencies to report annually on the number of classified human research projects and the number of subjects in each project. A preliminary review by the Administration's human radiation lnteragency Working Group indicates that the government is not supporting any classified human research at this time; today's directive initiates a formal, routine accounting of secret human studies.

A subcommittee of NBAC will address certain broad questions raised by ACHRE, including how to strengthen Institutional Review Boards -- the local ethics panels for Federally-sponsored research.     • In October, 1995 President Clinton directed agencies to develop plans to improve their oversight of ethics rules. The agencies have completed their review and upgraded protections, and NBAC will review agency procedures in the coming months.     • Agencies have undertaken nationwide education efforts to raise the profile of ethical considerations, and are funding research to improve our understanding of informed consent.

column5: The information in the record appears to be deliberative in nature and related to the internal decision-making process of the agency. Therefore, it may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which exempts from disclosure "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Supreme Court has held that this exemption covers documents that are both predecisional and deliberative, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice about the decision. See NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132, 150-51 (1975). ; ; In this case, the record appears to be a communication between agency officials discussing the progress of a report and potential briefing suggestions. The mention of O'Leary wanting to be involved in any announcement suggests that the agency is still in the process of making a decision about how to proceed. Therefore, the record may be considered predecisional and deliberative, and thus protected under exemption 5. ; ; However, without more context about the specific agency and issue at hand, it is difficult to make a definitive determination. The applicability of exemption 5 can depend on the specific facts and circumstances of each case.

column5: It is possible that this communication could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. Specifically, it could be argued that this email contains pre-decisional deliberative information related to the drafting and scheduling of an executive order, which is protected under the deliberative process privilege. However, without more context it is difficult to determine whether this communication meets the requirements for exemption 5 protection.; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege protects communications that are both pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that the privilege applies only to communications that are "actually predecisional" and "related to the process by which policies are formulated."

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? The Committee's report included recommendations to make the record of these experiments open to the public, improve ethics in human research  today, and right the wrongs of the past inflicted on unknowing citizens. In my remarks when I accepted the report, I promised that it would not be left  on the shelf to gather dust. I made a commitment that we would learn from the lessons that the Committee's report offered and use it as a road map  to lead us to better choices in the future.

column5: The email would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; SHIMABUKUR L@ A1 03/28/97 02:43:00 PM Record Type:    Record To: Elizabeth Drye cc: Subject: CLINTON TOUGHENS FEDERAL PROTECTIONS FOR HUMAN GUINEA PIGS Date: 03/28/97 Time: 12:27 RClinton toughens federal protections for human guinea pigs; ; WASHINGTON (AP) President Clinton took steps today to protect those who participate in secret, government-sponsored experiments from mistreatment and assure they are fully informed of the risks. The administration also said it has settled the last of a number of claims, totalling $6.5 million, from families of civilians who were injected with plutonium or uranium as part of secret experiments in the 1940s. The actions are• • designed to increase public trust ... and make our government accountable to the American people," said Energy Secretary Federico Pena, whose department has spearheaded the public review of past radiation experiments. Pena said the administration also will ask Congress to expand a program that provides compensation to uranium miners who were exposed to radiation as part of the government nuclear weapons program. He said up to 600 additional miners would be compensated at a cost of about $ 50 million. The plans for giving greater protection to research participants were prompted by recommendations more than a year ago by a presidential commission that investigated the government's use of humans in radiation research during the Cold War years. The advisory panel warned that past excesses might be repeated unless there are new safeguards. The White House said today that Clinton had signed a memorandum ,; strengthening the rights and protections afforded individuals who agree to be subjects of secret, government-supported research. The White House said a review by an interagency task force uncovered no government-supported classified human research at this time. But officials acknowledged that formal accounting for such research needs to be improved. Meanwhile, the White House said it had settled claims with four additional families of 1B individuals who were given plutonium injections as part of 1940s experiments. One victim has not been located and the family of another does not want compensation, said Tara O'Toole, DOE's assistant secretary for environment, safety and health. Associate  Attorney  General  John Dwyer  said the 16 claims        12 of which  totalling  $4.B million  were  made  public last November  total $6.5 million. The government has said it is prepared to provide compensation to the families of 52 other individuals who the advisory commission said were believed to be subjected to improper radiation experiments. The identity of those 52 are not known, and so far no families have come forward, according to the White House. Under the new presidential directive on human research, agencies must develop new rules that clearly require scientists to obtain informed consent from all potential subjects of secret experiments. Currently, such consent may be waived under some circumstances. The president also ordered that any research subject be told the identity of the sponsoring agency and whether the experimentation is classified. The new rules also would require the head of the agency to approve such research and develop a more independent review process than currently provided. Also in response to the October 1995 findings by the Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experiments, the president said he will: Ask Congress to broaden a 1990 law that allows compensation to underground uranium miners who became ill because of exposure to radiation. Under current law, hundreds of miners are ineligible for compensation. Will propose legislation to make veterans' health care benefits available to airmen and sailors who were subjects of radioactive nasal treatments more than 50 years ago. The treatments were to prevent broken eardrums during flight or in submarines. Will seek broader epidemiological studies to determine the long-term health impact of nuclear bomb testing during the Cold War to military personnel and civilian populations near the test areas. APNP-03-2B-97 1237EST

column5: It is possible that the document would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The document appears to contain internal agency communications regarding actions taken in response to a presidential advisory committee's questions and answers on human radiation experiments. This could potentially fall under the deliberative process privilege, which protects pre-decisional communications that are part of the agency's decision-making process. However, without more information about the content of the document and the specific context in which it was created, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege applies to documents that are "predecisional and deliberative in nature, and that contain opinions, recommendations, or advice about agency policies." However, the Court also noted that the privilege is not absolute and may be overcome if the requester can show a "sufficiently strong interest in disclosure" that outweighs the government's interest in keeping the document confidential.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Generally, the Committee found that researchers obtained consent from healthy subjects, but not from patient-subjects. The Advisory Committee did look more broadly at issues of informed consent across the government and found that the government did not have comprehensive policies in place before 1974. Although the government has strengthen informed consent procedures significantly since 1974, the Committee recommended -- and the Administration is taking -- additional steps to improve informed consent, including requiring informed consent in all classified research (eliminating a current waiver provision) and studying further the informed consent process.

For example, to open up the record, the Administration has put thousands of pages of documents on the Internet and in the National Archives, and has developed document search guides. To better protect human subjects in the future, the President established the National Bioethics Advisory Committee (NBAC) and asked NBAC to examine many of the questions raised by ACHRE. The Department of Justice has worked closely with other Departments to resolve individual claims. As announced today, the Administration has resolved all claims brought forward for experiments the Advisory Committee specifically identified for compensation. The Administration has settled with families of 16 plutonium injection subjects. The plutonium injection cases were singled out by the Advisory Committee as being particularly troubling ethically and deserving of compensation because efforts were made by the government to keep information secret from the subjects or their families to avoid government liabilities or embarrassment. The Advisory Committee also identified two other experiments for compensation (see Recommendation 1 ), but the subjects of those experiments are unknown.

column5: The message would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The message appears to be a communication between two government officials discussing a sensitive issue related to the Department of Justice. The mention of "productive discussion" suggests that the communication was part of a deliberative process, which is a key factor in determining whether a communication is privileged under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to "prevent injury to the quality of agency decisions" by allowing officials to engage in frank and open discussions without fear of public disclosure. ; ; In this case, the message between the two officials would likely fall within the scope of exemption 5 because it is an intra-agency communication that appears to be part of a deliberative process related to a sensitive issue.

column5: It is possible that the record described would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The mention of interviews and the involvement of White House staff suggest that the record may contain internal deliberations or communications related to the development of policy or decision-making. However, without more information about the content of the record, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 encompasses the deliberative process privilege, which protects predecisional communications that are part of the decision-making process and would be subject to disclosure if they were made public. The Court explained that the privilege is intended to encourage candid and frank discussions among government officials by shielding their internal communications from public scrutiny. However, the privilege is not absolute and may be overcome if the public interest in disclosure outweighs the government's interest in confidentiality.; ; In the case of the record described, the public interest in disclosure would depend on the nature of the information contained in the record and the context in which it was created. If the record pertains to a matter of significant public concern, such as the safety of human subjects in radiation experiments, the public interest in disclosure may be high. On the other hand, if the record contains sensitive or confidential information that could harm national security or other important government interests, the government's interest in confidentiality may be strong. Ultimately, the applicability of exemption 5 would depend on a case-by-case analysis of the specific facts and circumstances involved.

column5: It is difficult to determine whether the above record would be protected under FOIA exemption 5 without additional context or information about the content of the record. Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional, deliberative, and privileged. This means that the communication must be part of the decision-making process and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice that is intended to be kept confidential. ; ; Without knowing the content of the record, it is unclear whether it meets these criteria. However, the fact that it is a communication between two individuals within the Executive Office of the President (EOP) suggests that it may be protected under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports the application of exemption 5 to intra-agency communications is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (421 U.S. 132, 1975). In this case, the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 applies to "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." ; ; Overall, whether the above record is protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific content and context of the communication.

column5: The given record appears to be a communication between two government officials regarding a release of information by the President. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that are privileged and would not be available to a party in litigation. However, this record does not appear to fall under this exemption as it does not contain any deliberative or pre-decisional information. It is simply a communication regarding a public statement made by the President. Therefore, this record should not be protected under FOIA exemption 5.; ; Case law supporting this conclusion includes Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), which held that exemption 5 only applies to documents that are both pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. Additionally, NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), held that exemption 5 only applies to documents that are part of the decision-making process. As the given record does not contain any such information, it should not be protected under exemption 5.

column5: The above memorandum may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication within the Domestic Policy Council regarding proposed changes to the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA). The content of the memorandum may contain advice, recommendations, or opinions that are part of the decision-making process, and therefore may be considered privileged. ; ; However, without additional information about the specific content of the memorandum, it is difficult to determine whether exemption 5 would apply. For example, if the memorandum contains purely factual information or information that has already been publicly disclosed, it may not be considered privileged. ; ; One case that supports the application of exemption 5 to internal agency communications is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege protects communications that are part of the decision-making process and that would be inhibited if disclosed. Another relevant case is EPA v. Mink (1973), in which the Court held that the privilege applies to communications that are predecisional and deliberative in nature.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? DOJ has voiced concerns about this proposal.
column5: The above memorandum may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. The memorandum is an intra-agency communication between two government officials discussing a proposed policy change and the concerns raised by the Department of Justice. This type of communication is typically considered privileged because it involves the exchange of opinions and recommendations within the government decision-making process.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "those documents, and only those documents, that are normally privileged in the civil discovery context." The Court further explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect "the deliberative process of the government by ensuring that persons in an advisory role would be able to express their opinions freely to agency decision-makers without fear of publicity." ; ; Therefore, the memorandum discussing the proposed changes to RECA and the concerns raised by the DOJ may be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column5: The memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. The memorandum is an intra-agency communication between two government officials discussing proposed changes to a policy, and it is likely that the communication contains frank and candid advice or opinions that are intended to inform decision-making. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers communications that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature. The memorandum in this case appears to meet both of these criteria, as it is a communication between officials discussing proposed changes to a policy and seeking a decision by a certain deadline. ; ; Therefore, absent any other factors that would weigh against exemption 5, the memorandum would likely be protected from disclosure under FOIA.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? This approach would also include proposing the measures outlined in Section 1, above, for miners with greater than 50% probability.
column5: The memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. The memorandum is an internal communication within the Domestic Policy Council and contains recommendations and proposed actions. The deliberative process privilege, which falls under exemption 5, protects such communications that are part of the decision-making process and are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. ; ; In this case, the memorandum contains recommendations and options for proposed changes to the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA), and the author is seeking a decision from the recipient by a specific deadline. This suggests that the memorandum is part of the decision-making process and is pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. ; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), which established that the deliberative process privilege protects communications that are part of the decision-making process and are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. Additionally, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy (1981), the Supreme Court held that the privilege applies to communications that are "predecisional and deliberative, and that contain opinions, recommendations, or advice about agency policies." ; ; Therefore, the memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

Another case that supports this conclusion is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; MEMORANDUM FOR  BRUCE  REED FROM:   DIANE REGAS  Domestic Policy Council SUBJECT:    Proposed Changes to RECA - Decision Needed by January 7; ; ACHRE's recommendation to expand compensation without requiring individualized proof of causation is appropriate because of the egregiousness of the government's conduct, the impact  of the increased cancer rates in these communities and the government's  support for studying the miners without taking reasonable steps to reduce the known risk.
column5: The above memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication within the Domestic Policy Council, discussing a decision that needs to be made regarding proposed changes to the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA). The content of the memorandum appears to be deliberative in nature, discussing the appropriateness of a recommendation made by the Advisory Committee on Human Radiation Experiments (ACHRE) to expand compensation for individuals affected by radiation exposure without requiring individualized proof of causation. The memorandum discusses the reasoning behind this recommendation, including the egregiousness of the government's conduct, the impact of increased cancer rates in affected communities, and the government's failure to take reasonable steps to reduce known risks.; ; The deliberative nature of the memorandum would likely qualify it for exemption 5 protection, as it reflects the internal decision-making process of the agency and contains opinions, recommendations, and advice that are part of that process. The memorandum is not a final agency action or a factual record, but rather a communication that is part of the agency's decision-making process. As such, it would likely be protected from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), which established that exemption 5 covers communications that are part of the agency's decision-making process and that reflect the agency's deliberative process. The Supreme Court has also held that exemption 5 covers communications that are predecisional and deliberative, and that would be subject to disclosure if they were made after the agency's decision had been made. See United States v. Weber Aircraft Corp., 465 U.S. 792 (1984). In this case, the memorandum appears to be predecisional and deliberative, and would likely be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; MEMORANDUM FOR  BRUCE  REED FROM:   DIANE REGAS  Domestic Policy Council SUBJECT:    Proposed Changes to RECA - Decision Needed by January 7; ; Without a change, uranium miners who are not now compensated  under RECA  will continue to be held to a higher standard of causation than others who are compensated under RECA. Under RECA, people living downwind  of certain areas are compensated  ($50,000) if they  get  a radiogenic disease--even though the probability is very low (<10%) that the disease  was caused by the government's action. In addition, because RECA is not currently based on a probabilistic standard, a significant number of uranium miners who fall within the 20%-50% probability range in Option A are already eligible for compensation.  Option  A  would overcome some of these inequities.
column5: The memorandum would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The memorandum does not contain pre-decisional or deliberative information, but rather presents a proposal for a policy change and discusses the current inequities in the existing policy. As such, it does not fall within the scope of exemption 5. There is no need to cite case law to support this conclusion.

Second, the President announced that children of veterans  exposed  to agent orange  will  be compensated  with medical care if they are born with spina bifida. This decision  was tnade despite the extremely low probability of a connection and in the absence of biological plausibility. ·
column5: The memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. The memorandum is an internal communication within the Domestic Policy Council and contains advice and recommendations regarding proposed changes to the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA). The communication is also deliberative in nature, as it discusses the Clinton Administration's advocacy for compensation in cases where there is less than a 50% probability of physical harm caused by the government's actions. This type of communication is typically protected under exemption 5 to encourage open and frank discussions within government agencies. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "predecisional" and "deliberative" communications that are part of the decision-making process. Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 protects communications that are both predecisional and deliberative, and that disclosure of such communications would harm the decision-making process by inhibiting frank and open discussion.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? The expected cost of option A is only a fraction of this amount.
column5: The information in this memorandum would likely not be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. This is because the memorandum does not appear to contain predecisional or deliberative information that is typically protected under exemption 5. Rather, it appears to contain factual information about the cost estimates of proposed changes to RECA. ; ; Case law supports this conclusion. In Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, the Supreme Court held that "factual material" is not protected under exemption 5, even if it is contained within a deliberative document. 617 F.2d 854, 866 (D.C. Cir. 1980). Similarly, in Tax Analysts v. IRS, the D.C. Circuit held that "purely factual material" is not protected under exemption 5, even if it is contained within a deliberative document. 117 F.3d 607, 618 (D.C. Cir. 1997). Here, the cost estimates in the memorandum appear to be purely factual and not part of any deliberative process, so they would not be protected under exemption 5.

I expect that OSTP will also support this option, and OMB will express a view within the next day or so.
column5: The information in this memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication between members of the Domestic Policy Council, discussing proposed changes to the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA) and seeking a decision by a certain deadline. The mention of support from other agencies, such as the Department of Energy (DOE) and the Office of Science and Technology Policy (OSTP), suggests that this is a deliberative process involving multiple agencies and officials. As such, the information contained in the memorandum would likely be considered predecisional and deliberative, and therefore exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect the decision-making process of government agencies by allowing officials to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure. This rationale applies to the memorandum in question, which appears to be a communication between officials within the DPC and other agencies regarding a proposed policy change.

column5: The memo from DOJ attached to the memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. This exemption applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature. ; ; In this case, the attached memo from DOJ is likely predecisional because it is making a full argument on a proposed change to the RECA. It is also deliberative because it is discussing the pros and cons of Option B and providing analysis to aid in decision-making. ; ; The case National Labor Relations Board v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. established that exemption 5 applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative. In that case, the Supreme Court held that the exemption covers "recommendations, draft documents, proposals, suggestions, and other subjective documents which reflect the personal opinions of the writer rather than the policy of the agency." ; ; Therefore, the attached memo from DOJ would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; MEMORANDUM FOR  BRUCE  REED FROM:   DIANE REGAS  Domestic Policy Council SUBJECT:    Proposed Changes to RECA - Decision Needed by January 7; ; The general rule in litigation should remain that the government will only pay compensation if it is more likely than not that the government's action caused the harm. Any  decision  to expand the government's liability to other cases is setting a bad precedent. The possible result will be further expansion of the government's liability within RECA--possibly to new populations--and the creation of a model that may be used in entirely different circumstances.
column5: The memorandum may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The memorandum appears to be an intra-agency communication between two government officials discussing a policy decision related to the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA). The content of the memorandum expresses opinions and recommendations regarding the expansion of the government's liability within RECA, which could potentially be used in litigation against the government. Therefore, it may be protected under exemption 5 as it falls within the scope of privileged deliberative process materials. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects documents that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice related to that decision-making process. The memorandum in question appears to meet both of these criteria, as it is a recommendation regarding a policy decision that has not yet been made.

column5: The above memorandum may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication within the Domestic Policy Council, and the subject matter (proposed changes to RECA) suggests that it may contain deliberative or pre-decisional information that is exempt from disclosure. ; ; The case National Wildlife Federation v. United States Forest Service (861 F.2d 1114, 9th Cir. 1988) established that exemption 5 applies to documents that are both pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. The court held that "pre-decisional documents are those which were prepared in order to assist an agency decisionmaker in arriving at his decision, rather than to support a decision already made," and that "deliberative documents are those which reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process." ; ; Based on this case law and the limited information provided in the memorandum, it is possible that the document would be exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. However, a more detailed analysis would be necessary to determine whether the memorandum meets the criteria for exemption 5 protection.

The language used ("I recommend that you support Option A") suggests that this is a predecisional document, created before a final decision was made on the matter. Additionally, the fact that the memorandum is labeled "Decision Needed by January 7" further supports the idea that it is part of an ongoing decision-making process.; ; There is case law to support the idea that this type of memorandum would be protected under exemption 5. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (421 U.S. 132, 1975), the Supreme Court held that "predecisional" documents created during the deliberative process of an agency are protected under exemption 5. Similarly, in Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy (617 F.2d 854, 1980), the Fifth Circuit Court of Appeals held that documents containing recommendations and opinions related to a decision-making process were protected under exemption 5.; ; Therefore, it is likely that the above memorandum would be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; January 3, 1997 Office.of Legislative Affairs SUBJECT:    Proposed Amendments to RECA to Provide Partial Compensation to uranium Miners; ; This responds to your request for the views of the Civil Division on the amendments to the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA) which would authorize the payment of partial compensation to uranium miners for whom the probability is 50\ or less that their lung cancer was caused by exposure to radiation in the mines.
column5: The information in the document would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The document appears to be a communication between the Office of Legislative Affairs and the Civil Division, both of which are part of the Department of Justice. The content of the communication involves legal advice and analysis regarding proposed amendments to RECA, which would likely be considered privileged and confidential. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege under exemption 5 protects communications that are part of the decision-making process of an agency. The Court explained that the privilege is intended to encourage frank and open discussion among agency officials, without fear of public disclosure, in order to promote effective decision-making. ; ; In this case, the communication between the Office of Legislative Affairs and the Civil Division would likely be considered part of the decision-making process regarding the proposed amendments to RECA. As such, it would be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? We have worked hard to improve the administration of the program and are proud of what we have achieved and fully support the bulk of what has been proposed. We feel, however, that we must object to one of the proposals.
column5: The text provided would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The language used ("we helped to develop," "our experience in administering the program," "worked hard to improve the administration of the program") suggests that the communication is part of an internal deliberative process, which is typically protected under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1978), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The text provided appears to fit this description, as it reflects the authors' opinions and deliberations on proposed amendments to a government program.; ; Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. DOE (1981), in which the DC Circuit Court of Appeals held that exemption 5 covers "predecisional communications among agency personnel reflecting advice, opinions, and recommendations on agency policy." Again, the text provided appears to fit this description, as it reflects the authors' advice, opinions, and recommendations on proposed amendments to a government program.; ; Overall, based on the language and context of the text provided, it is likely that it would be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; January 3, 1997 Office.of Legislative Affairs SUBJECT:    Proposed Amendments to RECA to Provide Partial Compensation to uranium Miners; ; The current RECA provisions authorize the payment of $100,000 in compensation to miners who demonstrate that they were exposed to defined minimum levels of radiation. The legislative history of RECA indicates that Congress set the minimum exposure levels to approximate the point where, on average, it was more likely than not the miner's exposure caused his lung cancer; i.e., where the probability of causation was greater than 50%.1 RECA also authorizes the payment of compensation in the amount $50,000 to downwinders, persons who demonstrate that they were physically present in certain specified counties or geographic areas in the States of Arizona, Nevada, and Utah  during periods when atmospheric testing was carried out at the Nevada Test Site, and who suffer from certain statutorily specified radiogenic cancers.
column5: The information in this document would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The document appears to be a communication from the Office of Legislative Affairs, which is part of the Executive Branch, discussing proposed amendments to the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA). The discussion of the legislative history of RECA and the reasoning behind the minimum exposure levels could be considered part of the agency's deliberative process, which is protected under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The discussion of the legislative history and reasoning behind the minimum exposure levels in this document could be considered part of the agency's deliberative process in formulating proposed amendments to RECA. ; ; Additionally, the fact that the document is labeled "Office of Legislative Affairs" suggests that it may be a communication between agencies, which would also be protected under exemption 5. The D.C. Circuit has held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." Jordan v. U.S. Dep't of Justice, 591 F.2d 753, 774 (D.C. Cir. 1978). ; ; Overall, the information in this document would likely be protected under exemption 5 because it appears to be part of the agency's deliberative process and may also be a communication between agencies.

We support these proposals.
column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are deliberative in nature and would harm the decision-making process if disclosed. The text appears to be an internal communication within the Office of Legislative Affairs discussing proposed amendments to the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA) related to compensation for uranium miners. The language used suggests that the authors are discussing the Department's proposed legislation and expressing support for it, which could be considered part of the deliberative process. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "opinions, recommendations, and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Another relevant case is Wolfe v. Dep't of Health & Human Servs., 839 F.2d 768 (D.C. Cir. 1988), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 applies to "predecisional and deliberative" documents that are "part of the agency's deliberative process leading up to a decision."

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? column5: The proposed amendment to RECA discussed in the document would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The proposed amendment to RECA is a legislative proposal, not an inter-agency or intra-agency communication. Therefore, it would not be protected under exemption 5.; ; Case law supporting this conclusion includes Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), which held that FOIA exemption 5 only applies to inter-agency or intra-agency communications, not to documents that are purely legislative in nature.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; January 3, 1997 Office.of Legislative Affairs SUBJECT:    Proposed Amendments to RECA to Provide Partial Compensation to uranium Miners; ; It is our understanding that the rationale for these proposed amendments is to more nearly equalize the treatment of uranium miners and downwinders. Scientific evidence indicates that downwinders were exposed to much lower levels of radiation and, therefore, a much smaller increased risk of cancer, than were uranium miners. Therefore, the argument goes, it is unfair to allow downwinders whose probability of causation is below 50% to recover compensation while denying such recovery to uranium miners.
column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The text appears to be a communication between agencies (the Office of Legislative Affairs and another agency involved in proposing amendments to RECA) and contains legal analysis and advice regarding the proposed amendments. This type of communication is typically considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect "the quality of agency decisions" by allowing agency officials to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure. The text in question appears to fit within this definition of privileged communication.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? If the current scheme is providing payments to individuals whose illnesses more likely than not were not caused by radiation does not justify expanding payments to other individuals whose illnesses were not likely caused by radiation. We do not believe the case has adequately been made to overcompensate the miners which would be favored by the proposed legislation.
column5: The text provided would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; January 3, 1997 Office.of Legislative Affairs SUBJECT:    Proposed Amendments to RECA to Provide Partial Compensation to uranium Miners; ; Our main concern is that if this legislation is enacted, it can be anticipated that other groups will seek to be included in a similar way. For example, the geographical limits on the downwinder population will be subject to expansion. The counties and geographic areas currently specified in the statute exclude persons in adjacent counties and geographic areas where they were exposed to comparable levels of radiation from the nuclear testing program., Moreover, the costs of an expanding program are difficult to predict. For instance, the initial assessment of the cost of the Black Lung Program proved to be dramatically low.
column5: The passage would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature. The passage appears to be a communication from one agency (the Office of Legislative Affairs) to another agency or agencies, discussing concerns about proposed legislation and potential future implications. The communication is pre-decisional in that it is discussing a proposed amendment rather than a final decision, and it is deliberative in that it is discussing the agency's internal considerations and concerns about the proposed amendment. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated."

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; January 3, 1997 Office.of Legislative Affairs SUBJECT:    Proposed Amendments to RECA to Provide Partial Compensation to uranium Miners; ; Very importantly, expansion of the precedent for paying individuals compensation for injuries which, more likely than not, were not caused by the events triggering the compensation program is a profound policy decision. We would draw the policy line short of providing recovery for persons who probably were not injured by the government activities involved. The rule in litigation is that those who sue the government for injuries caused by governmental action must prove that the injuries were caused by the governmental action. [This standard is encompassed in 28 use 1346(b)] In many of these cases the plaintiffs may have a sympathetic case but lack the evidence to prove causation by the preponderance standard. Once the precedent is established that in some “exceptionable" cases the government, although not legally liable, is willing to legislatively compensate claimants, it will be hard to justify denying compensation to one group of citizens having granted it to others.
column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The discussion of legal standards and policy decisions would likely be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The text in question appears to be an intra-agency communication discussing legal and policy issues related to compensation for uranium miners, and would likely fall within the scope of exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; January 3, 1997 Office.of Legislative Affairs SUBJECT:    Proposed Amendments to RECA to Provide Partial Compensation to uranium Miners; ; Moreover, reducing the level of compensation does not derogate from the adverse consequences. The issue remains whether an individual should receive compensation for injuries most likely unrelated to the activities giving rise to the compensation. The bottom line is the same, the government would provide compensation even though most of the claimants receiving compensation would be compensated for injuries unrelated to the government's conduct. We believe the dangers of allowing compensation in these instances will invite many more such requests.
column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The text appears to be an internal communication within the government, specifically the Office of Legislative Affairs, discussing proposed amendments to the Radiation Exposure Compensation Act (RECA). The text contains opinions and analysis of the potential consequences of the proposed amendments, which are likely part of the agency's decision-making process. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "those documents, and only those documents, normally privileged in the civil discovery context." The Court further explained that the exemption "covers only materials that are both 'predecisional' and 'deliberative.'" Here, the text appears to be both predecisional (discussing proposed amendments) and deliberative (analyzing the potential consequences of those amendments). ; ; Therefore, the text would likely be exempt from disclosure under FOIA exemption 5.

The language used ("we recognize," "acknowledge," "we believe") suggests that this is a deliberative process, and the statement that "this proposal will be considered by Congress" indicates that it is not a final agency action. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Another relevant case is Wolfe v. Dep't of Health & Human Servs., 839 F.2d 768 (D.C. Cir. 1988), in which the D.C. column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; January 3, 1997 Office.of Legislative Affairs SUBJECT:    Proposed Amendments to RECA to Provide Partial Compensation to uranium Miners; ; We do not believe it is good public policy because it creates a new standard of compensation for one specific, favored group of citizens, which is not generally available to others whose claims may; in some instances, be equally or even more compelling. By making exceptions to certain favored groups rather than adhering to requirements equally applicable to everyone injured by the government, we will open a process in which groups may obtain relief more on the basis of their political ability than on the basis of an easily understood and accepted "more likely than not" standard. Once this policy Rubicon is crossed it will be easier for each successive group to muster its arguments that it is also deserving of a special exception. Ultimately, such deviation from the standard for "favored" groups may undermine the public's faith in the government's commitment to treating all of its citizens equally and undermine the public's support of such compensation programs.
column5: The passage would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The passage appears to be an internal communication within the Office of Legislative Affairs, and it contains the agency's deliberative process and policy analysis regarding the proposed amendments to RECA. The passage expresses the agency's opinion and concerns about the proposed amendments, and it reflects the agency's internal decision-making process. Therefore, it would likely be protected under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The Court explained that the exemption is intended to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies," and that it applies to "predecisional" and "deliberative" materials that are "part of the give-and-take of the consultative process." The passage in question appears to be precisely the type of predecisional and deliberative material that exemption 5 is intended to protect.

column5: The statement would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the exemption is intended to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies," and that "predecisional communications" are often protected because they "reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process." ; ; Another case that supports this conclusion is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The court explained that the exemption is intended to protect the "quality of agency decisions" by allowing agency officials to "speak candidly and freely" during the decision-making process. ; ; In sum, the statement would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5 as a deliberative communication that reflects the decision-making process of the agency.

column5: The content of the email would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The email does not fall under this exemption as it does not contain any inter-agency or intra-agency communication. Additionally, there is no indication that the email contains any privileged or confidential information. Therefore, the email would be subject to disclosure under FOIA. ; ; There is no specific case law that supports this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of FOIA exemption 5. However, the case of NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (421 U.S. 132, 1975) established the standard for determining whether a document is protected under FOIA exemption 5. The court held that the document must be both predecisional and deliberative to be protected. The email in question does not meet either of these criteria and therefore would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5.

But others familiar with the federal investigations into yield burning, including regulators and lawyers, contend that Wall Street's liability will be far less, perhaps in the tens of millions of dollars. The lawsuit cites the example of a 1994 Collier County municipal-bond refunding deal as typical of underwriters' practices. The suit alleges that Salomon Smith Barney charged the county too much to complete the transaction. The complaint added that the firm had "knowingly or recklessly failed to disclose"' to Collier County that it had charged the municipality an excessive mark-up on securities. The lawsuit also said that another firm had improperly certified the mark-up on the deal. A Salomon Smith Barney spokeswoman couldn't provide immediate comment on the lawsuit. Other firms named in the lawsuit, such as Morgan Stanley Dean Witter, Goldman Sachs, La=d and Lehman Brothers, declined to comment. In another yield-burning lawsuit, the City of New Orleans has sued Smith Barney and BT Alex. Brown Inc., a subsidiary of Bankers Trust Corp. over alleged yield burning. In September, La=d Freres paid about $9 million to settle a yield-burning lawsuit brought by a Los Angeles County agency.

Sosnik/WH,0-/E0P• I'-El-en-a-K-ag-an-/0P-D/E0P,; ; Politics & Policy: With Livingston Adding Power as House Speaker, Fight Gets Tougher for Organ-Allocation Reform By Laurie McGinley Starr Reporter of The Wall Street Journal PITTSBURGH -- On the day Rep. Robert Livingston was nominated as House speaker, John Fung sat in his office here looking glum. "Good for him," he said grumpily. Dr. Fung, who is the chief of transplant surgery at the University of Pittsburgh Medical Center, and the Louisiana Republican have emerged as weeks.' They weren't too thrilled.'' Rep. Livingston disputes that the delay will cost lives, saying that the rules themselves would threaten patients by discouraging donations. "Distributing organs from a national list and m more-centrahzed locations jeopardizes the liealth of the organ and d1mm1shes the mcenllve for people to donate in the first place," he said in a letter to his congressional colleagues last month. In any case, faced by Rep. Livingston's implacable opposition, HHS is striking a more conciliatory tone, trying to fmd ways to make the regulations more alatable. Officials emp  asize they aren't trying to dictate or  an-allocation  po 1c1es to the  m e  etwor   for haring, which staunchly opposed the rules, but are trying to get UNOS to develop new ways to reduce the geographic d1spanltes. "We have to work with Congress and the transplant community to resolve issues on this rule," says Claude Earl Fox, administrator of Health Resources and Services Administration, the HHS office that handles organ allocation. Referring to Mr..Livingston, the administrator  says, "The speaker is inundated right now, but we want to get together with him and his staff to continue the dialog on this." William Pfaff, president of UNOS and professor of surgery emeritus at the University of Florida in Gainsville, suggests that a mediator work to try to resolve the differences between HHS and UNOS. "I think using a facilitator would make sense," he says. In the meantime, Congress did authorize HHS to move ahead with part of its rules that would require UNOS and its transplant-center members to provide patients w1m more-ttmely mformat1on on such important issues as survival data. And it has ordered the respected Institute of Medicine, which 1s part of me Nat10nal Academy of Sciences, to study the issue and report back by May. Both sides are confident their position will be endorsed by the study. "If you can get care I 00 miles away from your home, that's better than 1,000 miles away," says Dr. McDonald. "That's obvipus."
