Begala/WH0/E0P }Maria Echaveste/WH0/E0P 1 Douglas B. Sosnik/WH,0-/E0P• I'-El-en-a-K-ag-an-/0P-D/E0P,; ; Marketing & Media: Golden Books Says Its President Quit To Be Marvel Chief By Patrick M. Reilly Staff Reporter of The Wall Street Journal NEW YORK - Golden Books Family Entertainment, the struggling children's book publisher, was dealt another blow as its president and second-in-<:ommand, Eric Ellenbogen, resigned unexpectedly to take a job as president and chief executive officer of Marvel Enterprises Inc. Mr. Ellenbogen, 41 years old, came to the company in 1996 as president of its entertainment group, a television and video-based unit. In June, he was named president of the entire company, acting as No. 2 to Richard E. Snyder, the parent's 65-year-old chairman and chief executive. At Marvel, he succeeds Joseph Ahearn, who previously said he would resign as soon as a successor was named. Marvel Enterprises was created in October when Marvel Entertainment Group Inc. emerged from Chapter 11 bankruptcy proceedings and merged with Toy Biz Inc. It owns the rights to several comic-book characters including "Spidennan," 11X-Men" and "Men in Black," as well as Fleer/Skybox, a trading-card maker, and the Panini stickers business. Mr. Ellenbogen was credited with building Broadway Video, a television production and distribution company, which Golden Books acquired in 1996. He directed Broadway's acquisition of crucial film and television libraries, including titles such as "Rudolf the Red-Nosed Reindeer," and "Lassie." The company said Mr. Snyder now will directly oversee the entertainment unit, which includes home video, merchandising and licensing. Golden Books' nine-month net loss widened sharply to $70.3 million, or $2.77 a share, and revenue fell to $142 million from $ f70 million. It recently reached a preliminary standstill agreement with a group of bondholders to put off interest payments on $100 million in debt. In a recent filing with the Securities and Exchange Commission, Golden Books said there is "substantial doubt about its ability to continue as a going concern." The company has warned that possible "restructuring, reduction of costs and other actions" could result in substantial year-end charges. Earlier this month, it was notified by the Nasdaq Stock Market about the possible delisting of the company's stock for failure to maintain a closing price of at least $5. The shares could be delisted . as early as Dec. 11, though the company says it plans to "work with the Nasdaq" to ensure its continued listing. Shares of Golden Books fell 6.25 cents to 43.75 cents in Nasdaq trading, close to a 52-week low. Marvel rose 6.25 cents to $5.9375 in composite New York Stock Exchange trading. Golden Books said Mr. Ellenbogen won't be replaced and said it will be "streamlining" its organization. The company said it will be "finalizing" its senior management in the next several weeks.

Sosnik/WH,0-/E0P• I'-El-en-a-K-ag-an-/0P-D/E0P,; ; Credit Markets: With Market Turmoil in the Rearview Mirror, Corporations Drive Forward With Bond Issues By Catherine Valenti and Tom Sullivan Staff Reporters of The Wall Street Journal Corporations of all stripes rushed to raise money in the bond market, including issuers who just six weeks ago wouldn't have stood a chance of raising funds.   As confidence  continued after the recent financial turmoil, problem-plagued ftanchis marketing company Cendant Corp. sold $1.55 billion ofbon increasing the size from a planned $500 million in response t strong investor demand. In addition, two telecommunications companies sold junk-rated securities to finance the construction new networks. Level 3 Communications Inc., which is using Internet technology, came to market with $500 million of zero-coupon bonds, while Global Crossing Holdings Ltd. sold $500 million of preferred stock to help finance its international fiber-optic links. Despite the rush, there is little sign the current flood of bond issuance will ease. It emerged yesterday that the Seagram Co. is lining up a giant debt offering, likely to come to market in December. Lead manager Goldman, Sachs & Co. is marketing the deal at a size of $2 billion. But there is widespread expectation among people looking at the transaction that the total could be raised to $2.5 billion to $4 billion. Goldman declined to comment on whether the size would be increased. No official confirmation of the use of proceeds was available. However Montreal-based Seagram is completing its acquisition of entertainment company PolyGrarn NV. The acquisition is valued in excess of$10 billion and is expected  to close  Dec. 4. With issuance rapidly making up any ground lost in September and early October, worries about a credit crunch are easing, though some participants say the real test will come after Thanksgiving with Seagram's deal and the $2.5 billion anticipated from Monsanto Co., announced two weeks ago. "The supply overhang that we saw all year is coming to the market and deals are getting done," said Greg Hahn, senior vice president and fixed-income portfolio manager at Conseco Capital Management. "That's a very healthy sign for the market  right now." The key to Cendant's deal was the high yield on offer, according to investors. That helped to overcome worries about the accounting scandal that has plagued the company this year. "Obviously  the company has had its accounting problems, but you can't  beat" the yield on offer relative to Treasurys, said John Kowalik, senior vice president and portfolio manager at Oppenheimer Funds. "If you're a yield  buyer, this would qualify as a candidate." Lead underwriters Chase Securities Inc. and Merrill Lynch & Co. said that even at the increased size, demand outstripped  the bonds available.   The company so/d $400 million of two-year notes at a yield 2.875 percentage points more than comparable Treasurys and $1.15 billion of five-year notes at a yield 3.125 percentage points more than Treasurys.    During the four-day roadshow to market the bond deal, syndicate officials said Cendant focused on the strength of its core businesses and strategy. For much of this year, the company's public image has been beset by an accounting scandal that took place at direct marketer CUC International, which merged with HFS Inc. to form Cendant in late 1997. As a further enticement, Cendant  will increase the coupon on the bond deal by 1.5 percentage points if its ratings are downgraded to junk status by both Moody's Investors Service and Standard & Poor's. Currently it is rated Baal by Moody's and triple-B by S&P. In the junk market, Global Crossing's offering of senior exchangeable pay-in-kind preferred securities was doubled from its originally planned size. The securities were priced at par with a 10.5% dividend rate. Level 3's deal was its second offering this year. It sold $3 billion of junk bonds in April and these securities have become a market favorite. During the financial crisis of mid-August to mid-October, "Level 3 became the only bond you could sell because it was a high-yield benchmark," said Jerry Paul, high-yield fund manager Invesco Funds Group, "and it was knocked down unduly." Level 3, which has a $10 billion capital plan, "saw a nice window to get some funds and got the money," said one person familiar with the deal. Neither Level 3 officials nor lead underwriter Salomon Smith Barney would comment. Here are the details of yesterday's two-year note auction. All bids are awarded at a single price at the market-clearing yield. Rates are determined by the difference between that price and the face value. Applications  $34,656,345,000 Accepted bids ............................. $16,014,345,000 Tenders submitted at market-clearing yld .. 60% Accepted noncompetitively   $815,215,000 Auction price (rate)    99.992 (4.629%) Interest rate ·····························4 5/8% Cusip number    9128274W9 The notes are dated Nov. 30, and mature Nov. 30, 2000.

column5: It is unlikely that the message would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, as it does not appear to contain any privileged or confidential information related to the deliberative process of government decision-making. Exemption 5 generally applies to inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional and deliberative in nature, and that would be exempt from discovery in civil litigation. ; ; In this case, the message appears to be a routine communication about a nursing home meeting, and does not contain any substantive discussion or analysis of policy options or recommendations. Therefore, it is unlikely that exemption 5 would apply. ; ; There is no specific case law cited in this scenario, but courts have generally interpreted exemption 5 narrowly and require a showing of specific harm to the deliberative process in order to justify withholding information. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 only applies to materials that are both pre-decisional and deliberative, and that the agency must demonstrate that disclosure would harm the decision-making process.

column5: The given information does not provide enough context to determine whether it would be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that are privileged and would not be available to a party in litigation with the agency. The information provided only includes the sender, recipient, and subject of the email, but not the content. Therefore, it is impossible to determine whether the email contains privileged information that would be protected under exemption 5. No case law can be cited to support a conclusion without additional information.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Deborah R. Adler 03/17/99 02:38:51 PM Record Type:    Record To: Laura Emmett/WHO/EOP cc: Subject: nursing home meeting; ; SUMMARY OF THE PROPOSED LEGISLATION The proposed legislation would give DOJ three new tools to combat the failure of nursing homes and other residential health care facilities to treat residents properly. First, it creates criminal sanctions for organizations or individuals who knowingly and willfully engage  in a pattern of  physical  or mental harm to residents. Second, it would create civil penalties that could be imposed on individuals, facility chains, or management companies if they engage in conduct that results in a pattern of  physical  or mental harm to residents. Third,  it would authorize  DOJ to seek injunctive  relief  against these entities or individuals whenever DOJ has reason to suspect  that  they are engaging  in behavior  that  will  result in harm to physical or mental harm to residents. DOJ would have to consult  with HHS before invoking  its injunctive authority.
column5: The above record would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that are privileged. This record does not appear to be an inter-agency or intra-agency memorandum or letter, but rather a summary of proposed legislation. Additionally, there is no indication that any privilege applies to this record. Therefore, it should be subject to disclosure under FOIA.; ; There is no specific case law cited to support this conclusion, as it is a straightforward application of the FOIA exemption 5 criteria.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Deborah R. Adler 03/17/99 02:38:51 PM Record Type:    Record To: Laura Emmett/WHO/EOP cc: Subject: nursing home meeting; ; OUTSTANDING ISSUES HHS is primarily concerned about the overlap in enforcement  authority  that these  new provisions would create. As currently drafted, the only area of facility noncompliance that would not pose the problem of overlapping authority for both agencies would be those cases where violations are minimal  or where the harm to residents is isolated. HHS is concerned  that  in situations  where both agencies have an interest in initiating an enforcement action, DOJ will push HCFA to delay its enforcement action, since DOJ's need  to build a solid case for conviction  may not coincide  with  HCFA's  need to act swiftly when needed. In addition, HHS is concerned that  DOJ  will develop  its own quality standards for individual facilities and chains when deciding whether to initiate prosecution, thus requiring facilities to comply with one set of standards developed by HCFA  and another  set of standards developed by DOJ.
column5: The passage would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter- or intra-agency communications. The passage appears to be an internal communication between HHS officials discussing concerns about potential conflicts between HHS and DOJ enforcement actions related to nursing homes. The communication reflects the agencies' deliberative process and contains opinions and recommendations that are likely protected from disclosure under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Dep't of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), which held that exemption 5 covers communications that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions or recommendations that were part of the decision-making process.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Deborah R. Adler 03/17/99 02:38:51 PM Record Type:    Record To: Laura Emmett/WHO/EOP cc: Subject: nursing home meeting; ; DOJ feels that the overlap in enforcement authority is limited to enforcement action in individual facilities. Currently, no one has the authority to prosecute nursing home chains for repeated violations, which this statute would provide to DOJ. In addition, this policy would not preclude  HHS from taking any action to protect the health and safety of residents, and DOJ is willing to codify this in an MOU.
column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are deliberative in nature and would be privileged in civil litigation. The text appears to be a communication between two government officials discussing the DOJ's position on a proposed statute related to nursing home enforcement. The text contains opinions and recommendations regarding the proposed statute, which would likely be considered deliberative in nature. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "recommendations, draft documents, proposals, suggestions, and other subjective documents which reflect the personal opinions of the writer rather than the policy of the agency." The text in question contains recommendations and opinions, and therefore would likely be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; Deborah R. Adler 03/17/99 02:38:51 PM Record Type:    Record To: Laura Emmett/WHO/EOP cc: Subject: nursing home meeting; ; PROPOSED DPC POSITION Modify the DOJ proposal to limit their new enforcement authority to criminal violations and require HHS to propose new legislation providing the111 with new authority to impose civil penalties. Under this option, the Department of Justice would be allowed to impose new criminal penalties on individuals, facility chains, and management companites who knowingly and willfully engage in a patterns of physical or mental harm to residents. HHS would propose new  legislation creating civil penalties that could be imposed on individuals,  facility chains, or management  companies if they engage in conduct that results in a pattern of physical or mental harm to residents. This compromise provides virtually the same level of enforcement and eliminates the problematic overlap of authority created by the DOJ proposal.
column5: The proposed DPC position would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The proposed position does not fall under this exemption because it does not involve communication between agencies or within an agency. It is a proposal for new legislation and does not involve any deliberative process or decision-making within an agency. Therefore, it would not be exempt from disclosure under FOIA exemption 5.; ; There is no case law cited to support this conclusion as it is a straightforward application of the FOIA exemption 5 criteria.

Jennings/OPD/EOP, Devorah R. Adler/OPD/EOP, Sarah A. Bianchi/OVP @ OVP cc: Subject: Crime Bill -- Nursing Home Provision
column5: It is possible that the records could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications and deliberative process privilege. The records appear to be internal communications among government officials discussing a nursing home meeting and a provision in the Crime Bill related to nursing homes. These communications may be considered part of the government's deliberative process and therefore exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; However, without more information about the content of the records and the specific context in which they were created, it is difficult to make a definitive determination. Case law has established that the deliberative process privilege protects communications that are predecisional and deliberative in nature, meaning they are part of the process of formulating policy or making a decision. See, e.g., NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132, 150-51 (1975). The privilege does not protect purely factual information or final agency decisions. Id. at 151.; ; Therefore, if the records contain purely factual information or final agency decisions, they would not be protected under exemption 5. On the other hand, if the records contain internal discussions or recommendations related to policy or decision-making, they may be protected under the deliberative process privilege.

column5: It is possible that the record described could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The subject matter of the record, a provision in a crime bill related to nursing homes, suggests that it may involve legal advice or deliberations among government officials. However, without more information about the content of the record, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers communications that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, meaning that they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions, recommendations, or thought processes related to that decision. The Court also noted that the exemption is intended to protect the "quality of agency decisions" by allowing officials to freely exchange ideas without fear of public disclosure.; ; If the record in question contains such predecisional and deliberative communications, it may be protected under exemption 5. However, if it primarily consists of factual information or other non-privileged material, it would not be covered by the exemption. Ultimately, the determination of whether a particular record is exempt under FOIA must be made on a case-by-case basis, taking into account the specific facts and circumstances involved.

Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are pre-decisional, deliberative, and privileged. If the message contains pre-decisional or deliberative information related to the development of policy or decision-making, it may be protected under exemption 5. However, if the message contains purely factual information or information that has already been finalized, it would not be protected under exemption 5. Without more information about the contents of the message, it is impossible to determine whether it would be protected under exemption 5. There is no case law cited in the prompt to support a conclusion either way.

Jones/OMB/EOP@EOP cc: See the distribution list at the bottom of this message Subject: Crime Bill -- Nursing Home Provision
column5: It is possible that this message could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, without more information about the content of the message and the specific context in which it was sent, it is difficult to make a definitive determination. ; ; If the message contains legal advice or attorney-client communications, it may be protected under exemption 5. For example, in NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), the Supreme Court held that attorney-client communications between an agency and its counsel were protected under exemption 5. Similarly, in Mead Data Central, Inc. v. U.S. Dept. of the Air Force, 566 F.2d 242 (D.C. Cir. 1977), the D.C. Circuit held that legal advice provided by an agency's counsel was protected under exemption 5.; ; However, if the message contains purely factual information or policy discussions, it may not be protected under exemption 5. For example, in Jordan v. U.S. Dept. of Justice, 591 F.2d 753 (D.C. Cir. 1978), the D.C. Circuit held that a memorandum containing policy recommendations was not protected under exemption 5 because it did not involve attorney-client communications or legal advice.; ; Ultimately, the determination of whether this message is protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific content and context of the message, as well as any applicable case law.

column5: The message would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within the executive branch. The message appears to be an internal communication between government officials discussing their legal analysis of a provision in a bill. This type of communication is typically considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect the "deliberative process" of government decision-making by allowing officials to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure. ; ; In this case, the message appears to be an internal communication discussing legal analysis and policy recommendations related to a provision in a bill. As such, it would likely be considered a privileged communication under exemption 5 and exempt from disclosure under FOIA.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; October 3, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF cc: FROM: RE: Sylvia Matthews, John Podesta, Bruce Reed, Gene Sperling, Frank Raines, Rahm Emanuel, John Hilley, Mickey Ibarra, Jack Lew, and Josh Gotbaum Chris Jennings NEW YORK AND THE PROVIDER TAX ISSUE; ; BACKGROUND Financing scheme. During the late 1980s, many states established financing schemes that had the effect of increasing their Federal Medicaid funds without using additional state resources. Typically, states would raise funds from health care providers (through provider taxes or "donations"), then pay back those providers through increased Medicaid payments. Since the Federal government pays at least half of Medicaid payments, the provider taxes or donations would be repaid in large part by Federal matching payments. Using this mechanism, the state was left with a net gain because it only had to repay part of the provider tax or donation it originally received.  This led to an unprecedented drain on the Federal Treasury - the major reason why Federal Medicaid costs more than doubled between 1988 and 1992.
column5: The memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication between high-level officials discussing a policy issue and providing background information. This type of communication is typically considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "those documents, and only those documents, that are normally privileged in the civil discovery context." The Court further explained that the purpose of the exemption is to "prevent injury to the quality of agency decisions" by allowing officials to freely discuss and debate policy issues without fear of public disclosure. ; ; In this case, the memorandum appears to be a communication between high-level officials discussing a policy issue, which would likely be considered privileged in the civil discovery context. Therefore, it would likely be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; October 3, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF cc: FROM: RE: Sylvia Matthews, John Podesta, Bruce Reed, Gene Sperling, Frank Raines, Rahm Emanuel, John Hilley, Mickey Ibarra, Jack Lew, and Josh Gotbaum Chris Jennings NEW YORK AND THE PROVIDER TAX ISSUE; ; The law and regulatory interpretation of the law. Because provider taxes and donations were effectively siphoning off potentially billions of dollars from the Federal Treasury, the Congress limited states' use of these schemes in a bill enacted by President Bush in 1991.  It is important to note that the subsequent regulatory interpretation of these limits -- the very regulations that we are now planning to enforce -- was negotiated with the states and the National Governors' Association in 1993.
column5: The above memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication between high-level officials discussing legal and regulatory interpretations of a federal law. This type of communication is likely to be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The memorandum in question appears to fit this description, as it is an internal communication between officials discussing legal and regulatory issues related to a federal law.; ; Another case that supports this conclusion is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 covers "predecisional" and "deliberative" materials that are "generated before the adoption of an agency policy and that reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process." The memorandum in question appears to fit this description as well, as it discusses the interpretation and enforcement of a federal law, which would likely involve a consultative process among agency officials.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; October 3, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF cc: FROM: RE: Sylvia Matthews, John Podesta, Bruce Reed, Gene Sperling, Frank Raines, Rahm Emanuel, John Hilley, Mickey Ibarra, Jack Lew, and Josh Gotbaum Chris Jennings NEW YORK AND THE PROVIDER TAX ISSUE; ; States' continued reliance on impermissible provider taxes and our enforcement record. Despite the new law and the regulations, many states continued to use provider taxes that at least appeared to be out of compliance. To date, these possibly impermissible taxes total an estimated $2 to 4 billion and, in the future, will cost billions more. In response, HCFA issued letters and discussed its concerns about certain taxes with states, but -- for a variety of reasons -- never took any final action (called a "disallowance"). Unfortunately, this has meant that a number of states have continued using these taxes, believing that HCFA might never enforce the law, or that if they did, they could seek recourse through the White House or the Congress. (In fact, since we do not have a good track record on enforcement, budget examiners at CBO and in the Administration have already written off Federal revenue raised through these provider taxes; this is important to know since it means we could waive past "abuses" retrospectively and it might not be scored as a cost.)
column5: The memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that are both pre-decisional and deliberative. The memorandum appears to be a discussion among government officials about the enforcement of regulations related to provider taxes, and includes opinions and recommendations for future action. This type of communication is typically considered pre-decisional and deliberative, and therefore exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects documents that are "predecisional and deliberative," meaning that they were "generated before the adoption of an agency policy and reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process." The memorandum in question appears to fit this description, as it discusses ongoing concerns and potential future actions related to provider taxes, rather than a final decision or policy.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; October 3, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF cc: FROM: RE: Sylvia Matthews, John Podesta, Bruce Reed, Gene Sperling, Frank Raines, Rahm Emanuel, John Hilley, Mickey Ibarra, Jack Lew, and Josh Gotbaum Chris Jennings NEW YORK AND THE PROVIDER TAX ISSUE; ; The New York provision in the balanced budget. To ensure that New York would never be vulnerable to Medicaid provider tax enforcement actions, Senator Moynihan and Senator D' Amato successfully added a provision to the Balanced Budget Act to exempt all of its provider taxes (it has dozens), both retrospectively and prospectively, from disallowances. Both in writing and orally we repeatedly objected to this provision. Moreover, we provided alternative statutory language that would have addressed about two-thirds (over $ I billion worth) of the problem. As you know, however, the Senators (through their staff) rejected our offer and insisted on their original provisions.
column5: The above memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum appears to be a communication between high-level officials discussing legislative strategy and negotiations, which would likely be considered privileged. Additionally, the memorandum contains references to alternative statutory language that was proposed but ultimately rejected, which could be considered deliberative and therefore protected under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The memorandum in question appears to fit within this definition, as it is a communication between agency officials and would likely not be available to a party outside of the agency.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; October 3, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF cc: FROM: RE: Sylvia Matthews, John Podesta, Bruce Reed, Gene Sperling, Frank Raines, Rahm Emanuel, John Hilley, Mickey Ibarra, Jack Lew, and Josh Gotbaum Chris Jennings NEW YORK AND THE PROVIDER TAX ISSUE; ; Line-item veto and New York's reaction. In announcing the line-item veto on August 11, we raised concerns about the cost and ramifications of singling out as permissible one state's provider taxes. Although our actions were generally viewed as responsible and defensible by those who know the program and/or who are budget experts, the same clearly cannot be said of New York's political establishment. The Governor's office, the New York Congressional delegation, the Mayor, providers and unions reacted strongly and negatively to the veto.  Among a host of complaints, they charged that they were singled out and were never made aware that this provision could be subject to the line item veto. Most recently they have criticized us for our . delay in getting back to them and our willingness to support fixes for the other two vetoed provisions without addressing their problem.
column5: The memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within the executive branch. The memorandum appears to be a communication between high-level officials discussing a controversial policy decision and the political fallout from it. This type of internal deliberation is typically considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to protect "the decision-making processes of government agencies" by allowing officials to engage in frank and candid discussions without fear of public disclosure. ; ; In this case, the memorandum appears to be an internal communication between high-level officials discussing a controversial policy decision and the political fallout from it. As such, it would likely be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; October 3, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF cc: FROM: RE: Sylvia Matthews, John Podesta, Bruce Reed, Gene Sperling, Frank Raines, Rahm Emanuel, John Hilley, Mickey Ibarra, Jack Lew, and Josh Gotbaum Chris Jennings NEW YORK AND THE PROVIDER TAX ISSUE; ; Review of provider taxes in New York and other states. In August, we began a review of the options to address provider taxes in New York and other states. At the time, we well knew that this action would force us to finally attempt to move to enforce laws against provider taxes in all 36 states that may be out of compliance. We also knew that we had to take this position to support our justification for the line-item veto that no individual state be singled out for special treatment.
column5: The memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum appears to be a communication between high-level officials discussing legal strategy and potential enforcement actions, which could be considered pre-decisional and deliberative. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. DOE, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), which held that exemption 5 applies to "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." ; ; Therefore, the memorandum would likely be exempt from disclosure under FOIA exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? We believe that our discussion with New York next Wednesday about their provider tax status necessitates that we concurrently release similar information to every other potentially affected state. Three types of actions resulting from this comprehensive review will be announced. First, HCFA will clarify its interpretation of the law and correct the regulation affecting one of the largest New York provider taxes. These policy  clarifications will provide relief to JO states, the largest amount (over $1 billion) going to New York. •

Sears, Roebuck & Co. (421 U.S. 132, 149 (1975)), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The memorandum in question appears to fit this description, as it is an internal communication between officials and would not be available to the public or other parties outside of the agency.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; October 3, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF cc: FROM: RE: Sylvia Matthews, John Podesta, Bruce Reed, Gene Sperling, Frank Raines, Rahm Emanuel, John Hilley, Mickey Ibarra, Jack Lew, and Josh Gotbaum Chris Jennings NEW YORK AND THE PROVIDER TAX ISSUE; ; Second, HCFA will issue letters to 9 other states notifying them that one or several of their taxes may be impermissible. Two more states, New York and Louisiana, will also receive this news, but it will be in a letter that also provides some good news about other provider taxes in their states. HCFA will immediately contact these states to begin discussions. The letters do not contain final decisions nor are they legally binding; however, they tell these states that, without further information, HCFA could conduct an audit.
column5: The information in the memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication between high-level officials discussing a sensitive issue related to healthcare provider taxes in various states. The inclusion of names and titles of the individuals involved suggests that the information is not intended for public dissemination. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums containing advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations" that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature. The memorandum in question appears to fit this description, as it contains recommendations and discussions about potential actions that HCFA could take in response to the provider tax issue. ; ; Additionally, the fact that the letters mentioned in the memorandum are described as not containing final decisions and not being legally binding further suggests that they are part of a deliberative process rather than a final agency action. ; ; Overall, it seems likely that the information in the memorandum would be protected under exemption 5, as it appears to be a privileged communication between agency officials discussing a sensitive issue in a predecisional and deliberative context.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? (Nine other states who are in one of the top two categories will get similar requests.) For these states, we simply do not have sufficient information to determine the legality of at least some of their taxes.  As we discuss this issue with these states, however, we will also make certain they are aware that they may be eligible for waivers that make their taxes permissible and/or that the provision of additional information may well clarify the legality of their taxes. [NOTE: All states affected are listed in the attached document; dollar amounts are not listed because we will not know them until/unless the states are audited.]
column5: The language in the memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication between government officials discussing the legality of certain provider taxes in various states. The discussion of legal analysis and potential waivers suggests that the communication is part of the agency's decision-making process and therefore falls under the exemption. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The memorandum in question appears to fit within this definition, as it reflects the agency's deliberations and decision-making process regarding the legality of certain provider taxes.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; October 3, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF cc: FROM: RE: Sylvia Matthews, John Podesta, Bruce Reed, Gene Sperling, Frank Raines, Rahm Emanuel, John Hilley, Mickey Ibarra, Jack Lew, and Josh Gotbaum Chris Jennings NEW YORK AND THE PROVIDER TAX ISSUE; ; Discussions and negotiations. The follow up to these letters will be, we hope, immediate discussions between HCFA and the states. Our primary goal is to protect the Federal Treasury prospectively. We may have to trade getting only a fraction of the retrospective disallowed taxes in return for expeditious agreements to prevent future use of impermissible taxes. However, the Department of Justice, which must approve all settlements, has not yet decided how it will evaluate these settlements. This information is crucial to HCFA's ability to negotiate with states in good faith.
column5: The information in this memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum appears to contain internal deliberations and discussions among high-level government officials regarding legal strategy and negotiations with states over the provider tax issue. This type of information is typically considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court explained that the purpose of the exemption is to "encourage frank discussion of legal and policy issues within the Government" by protecting the confidentiality of such communications. ; ; Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that exemption 5 applies to "predecisional" and "deliberative" materials that are "generated before the adoption of an agency policy and that reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process." The court explained that such materials are protected because they "reflect the agency's group thinking and therefore reveal the agency's deliberative process, which would be inhibited if such materials were made public." ; ; Based on these cases and the content of the memorandum, it is likely that the information would be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; October 3, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF cc: FROM: RE: Sylvia Matthews, John Podesta, Bruce Reed, Gene Sperling, Frank Raines, Rahm Emanuel, John Hilley, Mickey Ibarra, Jack Lew, and Josh Gotbaum Chris Jennings NEW YORK AND THE PROVIDER TAX ISSUE; ; Implications. Very few of the states who receive notices will be pleased. For example, although HCFA is relieving approximately two-thirds of New York's past impermissible tax claims (worth over $1 billion), there is still at least $500 million in taxes that HCFA probably cannot consider legal. The New York delegation has already put us on notice that nothing less than a "hold harmless" solution is acceptable. They define this as meaning that they want us to waive all current taxes both retrospectively and prospectively; in other words, they want the provisions we line-item vetoed.
column5: The above memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication between White House staff members discussing the implications of a healthcare tax issue in New York. The content of the memorandum suggests that it was intended to be confidential and not for public dissemination. ; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), which established that exemption 5 covers communications that are both predecisional and deliberative. The memorandum appears to be both predecisional (discussing the implications of a tax issue) and deliberative (discussing potential solutions and the reactions of various stakeholders). ; ; Additionally, the memorandum may also be protected under the attorney-client privilege, which is another type of privilege covered under exemption 5. However, more information would be needed to determine if this privilege applies in this case.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; October 3, 1997 MEMORANDUM TO THE CHIEF OF STAFF cc: FROM: RE: Sylvia Matthews, John Podesta, Bruce Reed, Gene Sperling, Frank Raines, Rahm Emanuel, John Hilley, Mickey Ibarra, Jack Lew, and Josh Gotbaum Chris Jennings NEW YORK AND THE PROVIDER TAX ISSUE; ; Those states most displeased will be the 10 others receiving letters that say that we believe that one or more of their provider taxes clearly appear to be out of compliance. They are: Hawaii, Illinois, Indiana, Louisiana, Maine, Massachusetts, Minnesota, Missouri, Nevada, and Tennessee. Governor Carnahan, who met with Jack Lew recently to discuss Medicaid issues, made it clear that he considers his taxes legal and will go to court if necessary. There is no question that Missouri has the largest problem -  they could owe nearly $1 billion.
column5: The content of the memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The discussion of legal compliance and potential litigation suggests that the communication is part of the agency's decision-making process and therefore falls under the deliberative process privilege. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The memorandum in question appears to fit this description, as it reflects the officials' opinions and recommendations regarding legal compliance and potential litigation. ; ; Additionally, the fact that the memorandum is addressed to a limited group of individuals and marked "cc" suggests that it was intended to be kept confidential within the agency. This further supports the application of exemption 5. ; ; Overall, the content of the memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5 due to its privileged and deliberative nature.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums containing advisory opinions, recommendations, and deliberations." Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), which held that the exemption applies to communications that are "predecisional" and "deliberative" in nature, meaning they were created before a final decision was made and contain opinions or recommendations that were part of the decision-making process. ; ; In this case, the memorandum is clearly predecisional, as it discusses various options and strategies for addressing the provider tax issue, and it contains recommendations and opinions from multiple officials. Therefore, it is likely that the text would be protected under exemption 5.

column5: It is possible that the above memorandum would be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum appears to be an internal communication between high-level officials discussing a policy issue, which could potentially be considered privileged. However, without more information about the content of the memorandum and the specific context in which it was created, it is difficult to make a definitive determination.; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that the deliberative process privilege under exemption 5 protects "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The Court emphasized that the privilege is intended to "prevent injury to the quality of agency decisions" by allowing officials to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure.; ; Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), in which the D.C. Circuit held that the privilege applies to "predecisional" materials that are "deliberative in nature," meaning they are "generated before the adoption of an agency policy and reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process." The court noted that the privilege is not absolute and may be overcome if the requester can show a "sufficiently strong interest in disclosure" that outweighs the government's interest in maintaining confidentiality.; ; Overall, whether the above memorandum would be protected under exemption 5 would depend on the specific facts and circumstances of the case, including the content of the memorandum and the purpose for which it was created.

column5: It is possible that this record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The record appears to be a communication between government officials discussing strategy and negotiations related to Medicaid policy. If the communication contains legal advice, attorney work product, or other privileged information, it could be exempt from disclosure under exemption 5.; ; However, without more information about the content of the communication, it is difficult to determine whether exemption 5 would apply. The fact that the communication involves political strategy and negotiations does not necessarily make it exempt from disclosure. As the Supreme Court has noted, exemption 5 is not intended to shield "mere discussions of policy" or "factual material" that is not predecisional or deliberative in nature (NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132, 151-52 (1975)).; ; Therefore, whether this record is exempt from disclosure under exemption 5 would depend on the specific content of the communication and the context in which it was created. If the communication contains privileged information, the agency could assert exemption 5 to withhold it from disclosure. However, if the communication is primarily factual or does not contain privileged information, it would not be exempt from disclosure.; ; There is no case law cited in the prompt to support a conclusion either way.

column5: It is possible that the above record could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. However, without additional context or information about the content of the record, it is difficult to make a definitive determination. ; ; If the record contains confidential advice or recommendations from agency officials to the President or other high-level officials, it may be considered privileged and exempt from disclosure under exemption 5. For example, in the case of NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., the Supreme Court held that "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency" are protected under exemption 5. ; ; However, if the record simply contains routine administrative or factual information, it would likely not be protected under exemption 5. For example, in the case of EPA v. Mink, the Supreme Court held that "purely factual, investigative matters" are not protected under exemption 5. ; ; Ultimately, the determination of whether the above record is exempt from disclosure under exemption 5 would depend on the specific content and context of the record.

column5: The above document may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The document appears to be a communication within the Executive Office of the President (EOP), which is considered an agency for FOIA purposes. The subject matter of the communication, an article on Medicaid, suggests that it may contain policy advice or recommendations, which are typically considered privileged.; ; However, without more information about the content of the document and the specific privilege being asserted, it is difficult to say for certain whether exemption 5 applies. For example, if the document contains purely factual information or if the privilege being asserted is not recognized under FOIA case law, exemption 5 may not apply.; ; One case that may be relevant is United States v. Nixon, in which the Supreme Court recognized a qualified executive privilege for certain communications between the President and his advisors. However, the scope of this privilege is limited and must be balanced against the public interest in disclosure. Other cases, such as In re Sealed Case and Judicial Watch v. Department of Justice, have further clarified the scope of exemption 5 and the types of privileges that may be asserted.; ; Overall, whether the above document is protected under exemption 5 will depend on the specific facts and circumstances of the case, as well as the legal arguments made by the agency asserting the privilege.

column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The text appears to be an internal discussion between two government officials about a potential policy decision, and it includes opinions and analysis that could be considered part of the deliberative process. The fact that the officials are discussing how to present the policy to the public also suggests that the text is part of the pre-decisional process. ; ; One case that supports this interpretation is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." Another relevant case is Coastal States Gas Corp. v. DOE, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), which held that exemption 5 applies to "documents that would reveal the mental processes of decisionmakers." ; ; Overall, the text appears to be a privileged communication that is part of the deliberative process, and therefore would likely be protected under exemption 5.

(I mentioned it on a call to  her in Portugal.)  So far  we've learned that Medicaid covers contraception (90% paid for by the Federal government)  and the  Federal Employees Health Program's main plan (Blue Cross/Blue Shield) covers it on the same basis as other prescription drugs. I'm still stuck  on the problem that we shouldn't  get into the business  of mandating coverage one body part at a time, but I do agree that it is a bit different since this bill would only put it on the same footing as other prescription drugs. I also learned at one of our Thursday morning "women's" meetings that requiring insurance companies to cover this polls very well. Anyway, more next week.

column5: The text would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within the executive branch. The email appears to be a discussion among White House staff about how to arrange a photo opportunity for the President, and as such, it could be considered part of the deliberative process and therefore exempt from disclosure. ; ; One case that supports this conclusion is Judicial Watch, Inc. v. U.S. Department of Justice, 365 F.3d 1108 (D.C. Cir. 2004), in which the court held that "predecisional and deliberative" communications among agency officials were protected under exemption 5. The court explained that the exemption was intended to "protect the quality of agency decision-making" by allowing officials to freely exchange ideas and opinions without fear of public disclosure. ; ; Similarly, in Armstrong v. Executive Office of the President, 97 F.3d 575 (D.C. Cir. 1996), the court held that communications among White House staff about a controversial issue were protected under exemption 5 because they were part of the deliberative process. The court explained that the exemption was designed to "prevent injury to the quality of agency decisions" by allowing officials to engage in "frank and open discussion" without fear of public disclosure. ; ; Based on these cases, it seems likely that the email in question would be protected under exemption 5. However, it's worth noting that the applicability of FOIA exemptions can be highly fact-specific, and courts have sometimes reached different conclusions in similar cases.

column5: As an AI language model, I do not have access to the attachment mentioned in the question. However, I can provide a general explanation of FOIA exemption 5 and relevant case law.; ; FOIA exemption 5 protects from disclosure "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." This exemption covers materials that are privileged, such as attorney-client communications, attorney work product, and deliberative process materials.; ; In determining whether a document falls under exemption 5, courts apply a two-part test: (1) whether the document is predecisional and deliberative, meaning it was created before a final decision was made and reflects the agency's deliberations and thought processes; and (2) whether the document would be privileged in civil litigation, meaning it contains legal advice or reflects the agency's decision-making process.; ; One case that illustrates the application of exemption 5 is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975). In that case, the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 protected from disclosure certain memoranda prepared by the National Labor Relations Board's staff that contained legal advice and reflected the agency's deliberative process in deciding whether to issue a complaint against Sears for unfair labor practices.; ; Without more information about the attachment in question, it is difficult to determine whether it would be protected under exemption 5. However, if the attachment contains legal advice or reflects the agency's deliberative process in developing a policy or making a decision, it may be protected under exemption 5.

Kassebaum-Kennedy took steps to prohibit genetic discrimination by preventing insurers from using genetic information as a "pre-existing condition" and  denying  or limiting coverage in group markets. However, Kassebaum-Kennedy falls short in three areas. It does not: ( 1) prevent health plans in the individual  market  from denying coverage  on the basis of genetic  information;  (2)  assure that premiums settings are in no way based on genetic information  both  in  the group and  individual  market; and (3) prevent health plans from disclosing genetic information  to  insurers,  to  plan sponsors,  and  other entities regulated by state insurance laws, such as life, disability, and long-term care insurers.

IRS, in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." In other words, if the information would not be available to the public through other means, it may be protected under exemption 5. In this case, the analysis of the limitations of the Kassebaum-Kennedy Act would likely not be available to the public through other means, and therefore may be protected under exemption 5.

column5: The statement "PREVENTING INSURANCE DISCRIMINATION BASED ON GENETIC INFORMATION" would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The statement in question does not fall under this category as it is not a communication between agencies or within an agency. Additionally, the statement does not contain any privileged or confidential information that would warrant protection under exemption 5.; ; There is no case law specifically addressing this statement, as it is a general statement and not a specific document or communication. However, case law such as NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1978) and United States v. Weber Aircraft Corp. (1973) have established the parameters for FOIA exemption 5 and what types of documents or communications are protected under it.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; PREVENTING INSURANCE DISCRIMINATION BASED ON GENETIC INFORMATION; ; Building on Kassebaum-Kennedy. Kassebaum-Kennedy took steps to prohibit genetic discrimination by preventing insurers from using genetic information as a "pre-existing condition" and denying or limiting coverage in group markets. However, Kassebaum-Kennedy falls short in three areas. It does not:(!) prevent health plans in the individual market from denying coverage on the basis of genetic information; (2) assure that premiums settings are in no way based on genetic information both in the group and individual market; and (3) prevent health plans from disclosing genetic information to insurers, to plan sponsors, and other entities regulated by state insurance laws, such as life, disability, and long-term care insurers.
column5: The passage would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5. FOIA exemption 5 protects "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The passage does not appear to be an inter-agency or intra-agency memorandum or letter, but rather a statement of policy or proposal for legislation. Therefore, it would not be protected under exemption 5.; ; Additionally, there is no case law cited in the passage to support a claim that it would be protected under exemption 5.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; PREVENTING INSURANCE DISCRIMINATION BASED ON GENETIC INFORMATION; ; State laws are insufficient. Nineteen states have already enacted laws to restrict the use of genetic information in health insurance and many others have introduced legislation. However, state legislation is insufficient to solve this problem. First, private sector employer sponsored health plans, which cover half of all Americans, are exempt from state insurance laws due to ERISA preemption. Second, current state laws generally focus on genetic tests rather than a broader definition of genetic information such as family history, medical records, and physical exams. Finally, the variability among state bills will lead to a lack of uniformity across the nation as to whether and how genetic information may be used by health plans.
column5: The passage would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5, as it does not pertain to inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are typically covered by this exemption. FOIA exemption 5 applies to materials that are "inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." (5 U.S.C. § 552(b)(5)). The passage provided does not involve such communications, but rather discusses the insufficiency of state laws in preventing insurance discrimination based on genetic information. Therefore, FOIA exemption 5 would not apply to this passage.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; PREVENTING INSURANCE DISCRIMINATION BASED ON GENETIC INFORMATION; ; Building on the existing bipartisan commitment to the President's challenge. Several bills have been introduced in this Congress which prohibits health plans from requesting or using genetic information to deny health care coverage or raise premiums. The bipartisan legislation introduced by Rep. Louise Slaughter, H.R. 306, addresses the three major gaps left by the HIPAA legislation and represents a strong foundation for this much-needed reform. It has already attracted over 150 cosponsors. The HHS report released today recommends building on this legislation and enacting a bill that protects all Americans from the threat of genetic discrimination.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? Explain your reasoning and cite any case law that supports your conclusion.; ; PREVENTING INSURANCE DISCRIMINATION BASED ON GENETIC INFORMATION; ; POTENTIAL GENETIC SCREENING EVENTS.
column5: The statement "PREVENTING INSURANCE DISCRIMINATION BASED ON GENETIC INFORMATION" would not be protected under FOIA exemption 5 as it does not fall under any of the categories of information that are exempted under this provision. FOIA exemption 5 applies to inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are privileged or confidential, such as attorney-client communications, deliberative process privilege, and attorney work product. However, the statement "POTENTIAL GENETIC SCREENING EVENTS" may be protected under FOIA exemption 5 if it is part of an inter-agency or intra-agency communication that meets the criteria for exemption. For example, if the statement is part of a confidential memo or email exchange between government officials discussing the potential use of genetic screening in a particular program or policy, it may be exempted under the deliberative process privilege. However, without additional context, it is difficult to determine whether this statement would be exempted under FOIA exemption 5. ; ; Case law: In Milner v. Department of the Navy, 562 U.S. 562 (2011), the Supreme Court held that FOIA exemption 5 only applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative. The Court also clarified that the deliberative process privilege only protects communications that are part of the decision-making process, such as recommendations, opinions, and advice. The privilege does not protect purely factual information or final agency decisions.

column5: The above statement may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The statement appears to describe internal deliberations and discussions between high-level government officials regarding a policy initiative. The fact that the meeting was private and involved multiple agencies suggests that it was a confidential communication intended to facilitate decision-making. ; ; One case that supports this interpretation is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1978), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "intra-agency memorandums or letters which would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency." The Court emphasized that the exemption is intended to protect the "decision-making processes of government agencies" by allowing officials to communicate candidly and freely without fear of public disclosure. ; ; In this case, the statement about the meeting between McCaffrey, Reno, and Rubin appears to be an internal communication that would not be available to the public or to outside parties. It also appears to relate to the decision-making process of government agencies, specifically the formulation of recommendations to the President regarding a policy initiative. Therefore, it is likely that this statement would be protected under exemption 5.

column5: It is possible that the above statement could be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within the executive branch. The statement appears to involve internal deliberations and discussions about how to present a decision to the President, which could be considered part of the decision-making process and therefore privileged. However, without more context it is difficult to determine whether this statement would meet the requirements for exemption 5.; ; One case that may be relevant is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975), in which the Supreme Court established the "deliberative process privilege" as a subset of exemption 5. This privilege protects communications that are part of the decision-making process and would reveal the agency's deliberations, thought processes, or recommendations if disclosed. However, the privilege only applies to pre-decisional communications, meaning that once a decision has been made, the privilege no longer applies. About 60 percent of the cocaine entering the U.S. does so across this border, yet seizures in the border region are declining. Total 1998 cocaine seizures are projected to be less than half of the annual average seized between 1991 and 1996 and account for just a fifth of the cocaine crossing the border. Heroin seizures have declined by about a third since 1996. Over the past several years, the general trend has been one of fewer seizures of all drugs except marijuana. column5: The above memorandum may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged inter-agency or intra-agency communications. This exemption applies to documents that are both predecisional and deliberative in nature. ; ; In this case, the memorandum is addressed to the President and contains recommendations for organizing drug control efforts along the Southwest border. The language used suggests that the memorandum is predecisional, meaning that it was created before a final decision was made on how to organize these efforts. Additionally, the memorandum contains recommendations and proposals for action, which suggests that it is deliberative in nature. ; ; One case that supports the application of exemption 5 to similar documents is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co. (1975). In this case, the Supreme Court held that documents containing recommendations and proposals for action were protected under exemption 5 because they were both predecisional and deliberative. ; ; Therefore, it is possible that the above memorandum would be protected under FOIA exemption 5. However, it is important to note that the application of this exemption is highly fact-specific and can vary depending on the circumstances of each case.

column4: Would the following be protected under FOIA exemption 5? column5: The above memorandum may be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers privileged communications within or between agencies. The memorandum is addressed to the President and contains advice and recommendations on drug control efforts along the Southwest border. This suggests that it may be a deliberative document, which is a type of privileged communication that is protected under exemption 5.; ; Deliberative documents are those that are created as part of the decision-making process and contain opinions, recommendations, or advice that are intended to inform or influence the decision-maker. They are protected because they reflect the agency's internal deliberations and are considered essential to the decision-making process. The purpose of exemption 5 is to encourage frank and open communication within agencies by protecting the confidentiality of these deliberative documents.; ; In the case of NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., the Supreme Court established a two-part test for determining whether a document is protected under exemption 5. First, the document must be predecisional, meaning that it was created before the agency made a final decision on the matter. Second, the document must be deliberative, meaning that it contains opinions, recommendations, or advice that are intended to inform or influence the decision-maker.; ; Applying this test to the memorandum in question, it appears that the document may be protected under exemption 5. The memorandum is addressed to the President, who is the ultimate decision-maker on drug control efforts along the Southwest border. The recommendations and advice contained in the memorandum are intended to inform and influence the President's decision-making process. Therefore, the memorandum is both predecisional and deliberative, and may be protected under exemption 5.; ; However, it is important to note that exemption 5 is not an absolute privilege. The government must still balance the public's interest in disclosure against the government's interest in keeping the document confidential. If the public interest in disclosure outweighs the government's interest in confidentiality, the document may be subject to disclosure under FOIA.

column5: The above memorandum would likely be protected under FOIA exemption 5, which covers inter-agency or intra-agency communications that are privileged or confidential. The memorandum is a communication from one government official (Barry McCaffrey) to another (the President), and it contains advice and recommendations on how to organize drug control efforts along the Southwest border. This type of communication is typically considered privileged and confidential because it involves the exchange of sensitive information and opinions between government officials who need to be able to speak candidly and freely in order to make informed decisions.; ; One case that supports this conclusion is NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "documents reflecting advisory opinions, recommendations and deliberations comprising part of a process by which governmental decisions and policies are formulated." The memorandum in question clearly falls within this category, as it contains McCaffrey's recommendations and advice on how to address drug-related corruption and violence along the Southwest border.; ; Another case that supports this conclusion is Dep't of the Interior v. Klamath Water Users Protective Ass'n, 532 U.S. 1 (2001), in which the Supreme Court held that exemption 5 covers "predecisional" documents that are "deliberative in nature" and "reflect the give-and-take of the consultative process." The memorandum in question is clearly predecisional, as it contains McCaffrey's recommendations and advice on how to organize drug control efforts along the Southwest border. It is also deliberative in nature, as it reflects McCaffrey's thought process and the give-and-take of the consultative process that led to his recommendations.

CONCLUSION. The fourth goal of your 1998 National Drug Control Strategy is to "Shield America's air, land, and sea frontier from the drug threat." Over the past five years, your Administration has invested heavily in anti-drug programs to secure the two-thousand mile border with Mexico. As a result, Customs' budget for Southwest Border programs has increased 72 percent since FY93. The number of assigned DEA special agents has increased 37 percent while the number of assigned INS agents has almost doubled. Toe enclosed ONDCP White Paper suggests how better coordination can dramaticaly improve the effectiveness of our collective efforts. We look forward to submitting a detailed proposal for your consideration this fall.

column5: It is not possible to determine whether the document would be protected under FOIA exemption 5 without knowing the content of the document. Exemption 5 protects inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that would not be available by law to a party other than an agency in litigation with the agency. The exemption is intended to protect the decision-making process of the government by allowing for frank and open discussions among government officials. However, the exemption does not protect information that is purely factual or that has already been publicly disclosed.; ; Therefore, without knowing the content of the document, it is impossible to determine whether it would be protected under exemption 5. However, if the document contains inter-agency or intra-agency memorandums or letters that are part of the decision-making process and have not been publicly disclosed, it may be protected under exemption 5.; ; Case law that supports this conclusion includes NLRB v. Sears, Roebuck & Co., 421 U.S. 132 (1975), which established the deliberative process privilege, and Coastal States Gas Corp. v. Department of Energy, 617 F.2d 854 (D.C. Cir. 1980), which clarified that the privilege applies to predecisional and deliberative documents.
